content.description: Start sitting with left hand on a good crimp and right hand around the arete on a poor sloper. There are a couple options for the right foot and the left is a smear. Make a tough move of the ground and bump your right hand up the slopers to a slopey top out.
content.location: On the smallest of the three boulders on the right side of the trail, this climbs the blunt arete points to the trail. The left face has a positive crimp and a slopey rail running across it at mid height.

content.description: This short, extremely fingery problem is the hardest in the Dwarf Boulders.  Sit start between Freddy & the Emperor with two terrible crimps in the thin seam.  With the decent foot hold, pull off the ground and out right to the edge on the arete of Emperor.  Match and finish straight up the arete to an easy topout.
content.location: On the Dwarf boulder furthest from the trail, this climbs the seam and arete facing away from the trail.  Downclimb to the smaller boulder.

content.description: An embarrassing slab encounter that is more fun and more difficult than it looks.  Using two cool slopers on the right of the arete, stand start with a large foothold, then friction, lieback, smear, and slap up to the top.  Topout into the branches.
content.location: This is the front left arete of the large boulder closest to the road.  Downclimb off right on the short slab.

content.description: Want to squeeze some slopey aretes?  Yes?  Good.  Hopefully the friction cooperates.  This sweet little warmup hugs up the butt of the boulder for a couple of moves before letting you rock over the top on a great big jug.  Sit start in front of the tree with left hand on the left arete and right hand on the right arete.  Using a small, positive left foot, pull off the ground, heelhook, and follow the arete up until you can snag the obvious jug.  Pull over and stand up.  Now go back and do it again.
content.location: This problem graces the backside of the largest boulder of the three.  The boulder is on the downhill side and also the first you encounter when walking towards them.  The problem starts just left of the small overhang.

content.description: A surprisingly tricky arete with crystally holds and great friendly slopers.  Sit start right of a small rock with a slopey sidepull for your right hand and a large undercling for your left.  There is only one starting foot, so put your left foot on it.  Pull off the ground (crux) and gaston the crystal jug.  Match, then move left to a cool sloper, then straight up to another sloper on the top for the topout.
content.location: This problem is on the back of the mid sized boulder on the right.  It happens to be the problem furthest from the trail, all of a 20 second approach.  Downclimb off the back of the boulder.

content.description: A quick little arete with good holds and fun moves.  Sit start with the good right foot and a smear for the left.  Grab the sidepull on the arete with both hands and pop to the slopey edge on the left of the arete (crux).  Make a big move to the lip (possibly using an intermediate crimp for balance) and topout on good holds.
content.location: There are only 3 boulders here.  This one is the mid sized one or the back right one coming from the road.  The problem climbs the sharp downhill arete.  Downclimb off the back of the boulder.

content.description: A low angle arete with great pinches and a crux first move.  Sit start the base of the arete on the right with both hands matched on a seam.  Put your right foot on the large hold.  Pull off the ground and slap up the arete.  Make a few moves up the nice arete and topout.  A great warmup with friendly holds.
content.location: This is the front right arete of the large boulder closest to the road.  Downclimb off right on the short slab.

content.description: One quick move leads to a mantle and the problem is over far too quickly.  Sit start beneath the short bulge/roof with a left hand crimp and a high right hand sloper.  Pull off the ground and toss around the bulge to the lip.  Match and top it out.
content.location: Uphill and across the trail from the Dwarf Boulders proper, this short bulge is hard to miss and is the first piece of rock encountered on a walk down the Fire Road.

content.description: Stand start with a bad lefthand crimp in the seam and an even worst right hand in the same seam. Find the positioning and pull off the ground. Once established on the wall, pop to the lip and topout.
content.location: On the second boulder from the trail. This problem is on the downhill side of the boulder. Around right from Rumplestiltskin.

content.description: Aren't they cute?  How many times have people walked by without even sampling the handful of fun warmup climbs on these three small boulders?  Mostly in the shade, the boulders need some company, and if you visit, you'll probably wind up entirely lonely on quality rock.  The climbs may be short, but give them a try one day.  Jump on Horton Hears a Who, The Emporers New Groove, or the Lost Dwarf and enjoy the friction.
